ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to live virtual lecture, we had asynchronous classes where we did work on our own.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have a much firmer grasp on the language. My speaking capability has improved tremendously, as well as my knowledge of grammar and vocabulary.
My Spanish greatly improved! I learned a lot of grammar and vocabulary. The extra listening and cultural help that the professor put on canvas was very helpful.
I learned a lot of Spanish grammar, reading comprehension, and vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Virtual was not horrible but in-person for language would be better. I wish we could have had more discussion/practice between students.

The online book resources and homework is not very helpful.
I would not do the asynchronous days next semester. I liked the thought of not having us on Zoom so much, but I found that I learned less from those classes than the synchronous ones.
It so heavily focused on grammar yet 20% of your grade is oral and listening.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I appreciated all the extra information and practice that the professor put on Canvas. It was very self-guided instruction which was nice.

I wish there had been more time to just "talk in Spanish" with the teacher about anything/everything. It was much more limited with the virtual engagement.
I felt more engaged in this class than any other this semester! I really enjoyed chatting with other students and the professor each lecture and practicing my Spanish speaking.
Communicating when assignments were due was poor. The syllabus was confusing at times.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend taking SPAN 120 with Professor Tortora. She is very kind and great at teaching the language.
Yes. I would say this is a great way to learn more Spanish, but prepare for a daily workload.
No, grading in the Spanish department is a GPA killer.
